'''Separatism''' is the advocacy of a state of cultural, ethnic, tribal, religious, racial, governmental or gender separation from the larger group. While it often refers to full political [[secession]],<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/separatism Free Dictionary]; [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/separatism Merriam Webster dictionary]; [http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O999-separatist.html ''The Oxford Pocket Dictionary of Current= English 2008''].</ref> separatist groups may seek nothing more than greater autonomy.<ref>R. Harris, Jerry Harris, ''The Nation in the Global Era: Conflict and Transformation'', Brill, 2009, [http://books.google.com/books?id=UQQujqyOJJIC&pg=PA320&dq=separatism+greater+autonomy&hl=en&ei=h8nVTKHnOsP88AaEsNnWCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=separatism%20greater%20autonomy&f=false p. 320], ISBN 90-04-17690-X, 9789004176904</ref> Some groups refer to their organizing as [[independence]], [[self-determination]], [[Partition (politics)|partition]] or [[decolonization]] movements instead of, or in addition to, [[autonomist]], separatist or secession movements.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} While some critics may equate separatism and [[religious segregation]], [[racial segregation]] or [[sexual segregation]], separatists argue that separation by choice is not the same as government-enforced segregation and may serve useful purposes.<ref>John Leo, [http://www.city-journal.org/html/eon2007-06-13jl.html "Let the Segregation Commence, Separatist graduations proliferate at UCLA"], [[City Journal (New York)|''City Journal'']], June 13, 2007</ref><ref>Nancy Levit, [http://home.law.uiuc.edu/lrev/publications/2000s/2005/2005_2/Levit.pdf Embracing Segregation: The Jurisprudence of Choice and Diversity in Race and Sex Separatism in Schools (PDF)], ''University of Illinois Law Review'', August 29, 2005, 455.</ref><ref>Karen W. Arenson, [http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/19/education/19male.html CUNY Program to Help Black Men Is Called Discriminatory], ''[[New York Times]]'', April 19, 2006.</ref><ref>Betty A. Dobratz, Stephanie L. Shanks-Meile, [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3719/is_200607/ai_n16855771 Strategy of White Separatism], ''Journal of Political and Military Sociology'', Summer 2006.</ref><ref>Nancy B. Howell, [http://www.religion-online.org/showarticle.asp?title=2773 Radical Relatedness and Feminist Separatism.]</ref>
==Motivations for separatism== Groups may have one or more motivations for separation, including<ref>Metta Spencer, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Dz6vDcL8Q90C ''Separatism: Democracy and Disintegration''], Rowan & Littlefield, 1998, 2-4.</ref>: * emotional resentment of rival communities * protection from ethnic cleansing and genocide * justified resistance by victims of oppression, including denigration of their language, culture or religion * propaganda by those who hope to gain politically from intergroup conflict and hatred * the economic and political dominance of one group that does not share power and privilege in an egalitarian fashion * economic motivations: seeking to end economic exploitation by more powerful group or, conversely, to escape economic redistribution from a richer to a poorer group * preservation of threatened religious, language or other cultural tradition * destabilization from one separatist movement giving rise to others * geopolitical power vacuum from breakup of larger states or empires * continuing fragmentation as more and more states break up. * feeling that the perceived nation was added to the larger state by illegitimate means * the perception that the state can no longer support one's own group or has betrayed their interests
==Governmental responses== How far separatist demands will go toward full independence, and whether groups pursue constitutional and nonviolent or armed violence, depend on a variety of economic, political, social and cultural factors, including movement leadership<ref>[http://www.allacademic.com/one/prol/prol01/index.php?click_key=1 Link to:] Chima, Jugdep. "Effects of Political Leadership on Ethnic Separatist Movements in India" Paper presented at the annual meeting of the Midwest Political Science Association, Palmer House Hotel, Chicago, Illinois, April 12, 2007 (PDF); Chima, Jugdep. "How Does Political Leadership Affect the Trajectories of Ethnic Separatist Insurgencies?: Comparative Evidence from Movements in India" Paper presented at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association, Marriott Wardman Park, [[Omni Shoreham]], Washington Hilton, Washington, D.C., September 01, 2005 (PDF).</ref> and the government's response.<ref name="Horowitz">See D.L. Horowitz's "Patterns of Ethnic Separatism", originally published in ''Comparative Studies in Society and History'', 1981, vol 23, 165-95. Republished in John A. Hall, ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=9_matAX1z8cC The State: Critical Concepts]'', Routledge, 1994.</ref> Governments may respond in a number of ways, some of which are mutually exclusive. Some include:<ref>Metta Spencer, 5-6.</ref> * accede to separatist demands * improve the circumstances of disadvantaged minorities, be they religious, linguistic, territorial, economic or political * adopt "asymmetric federalism" where different states have different relations to the central government depending on separatist demands or considerations * allow minorities to win in political disputes about which they feel strongly, through parliamentary voting, referendum, etc. * settle for a [[confederation]] or a [[commonwealth]] relationship where there are only limited ties among states. Some governments suppress any separatist movement in their own country, but support separatism in other countries.
==Types of separatist groups== Separatist groups practice a form of [[identity politics]] - "political activity and theorizing founded in the shared experiences of injustice of members of certain social groups." Such groups believe attempts at integration with dominant groups compromise their identity and ability to pursue greater self-determination.<ref name="Stanford">[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/identity-politics/ Identity Politics], [[Stanford University]] Encyclopedia of Philosophy, November 2, 2007.</ref> However, economic and political factors usually are critical in creating strong separatist movements as opposed to less ambitious identity movements.<ref name="Horowitz"/>
''See more complete lists of [[List of historical autonomist and secessionist movements|historical]] and [[List of active autonomist and secessionist movements|active]] autonomist and secessionist movements, as well as a [[list of unrecognized countries]].''
===Religious=== [[Religion|Religious]] separatist groups and sects want to withdraw from some larger religious groups and/or believe they should interact primarily with co-religionists. * English Christians in the 16th and 17th centuries who wished to separate from the [[Church of England]] and form independent local churches were influential politically under [[Oliver Cromwell]], who was himself a separatist. They were eventually called [[Congregationalists]].<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9042265/Separatist#277127.hook Encyclopædia Britannica on religious separatists.]</ref> The [[Pilgrim (Plymouth Colony)|Pilgrims]] who established the first successful colony in [[New England]] were separatists.<ref>John Abbot Goodwin, ''The Pilgrim republic: an historical review of the colony of New Plymouth...'', Houghton Mifflin Company, 1888, [http://books.google.com/books?id=1h86ThQYxgEC&pg=PA1&dq=pilgrims+separatists&ei=6tt6SunrKJHyyAT46JnEDA&client=firefox-a#v=onepage&q=pilgrims separatists&f=false p. 1]</ref> * Christian separatist groups in [[Maluku Sovereignty Front|Indonesia]],<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/2202709.stm Christian separatist on trial in Indonesia], [[BBC]], August 19, 2002.</ref><ref>Chris Brummitt, [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-51830871.html Christian separatist leader threatens to raise independence flags in Maluku], [[Associated Press]], April 5, 2002.</ref> India<ref>Syed Zarir Hussain, [http://www.mail-archive.com/goanet@goacom.com/msg03883.html Christian separatist group in Tripura target tribal Hindus], Indo-Asian News Service, December 31, 2002/</ref> and [[South Carolina]] (United States).<ref>[http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2007/jun/09/no-headline---le1fcbottom09/?printer=1/ Christian separatist ready for new home], ''Ventura County Star'', June 9, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.wistv.com/Global/story.asp?S=3956568&nav=0RaP Colorado Rep. disavows ties to SC Christian separatist group], [[Associated Press]], October 9, 2005.</ref> * [[Catholics]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. * [[Zionism]] sought the creation of the state of [[Israel]] as a [[Jewish]] homeland. This resulted in religious separatism between the Jewish Israelis, and Muslim and Christian Palestinians following the [[Balfour Declaration of 1917|Balfour Declaration]]. [[Simon Dubnow]], who was ambivalent toward Zionism, formulated [[Jewish Autonomism]] which was adopted in eastern Europe by Jewish political parties such as the [[General Jewish Labour Bund in Lithuania, Poland and Russia|Bund]] and his own [[Folkspartei]] before World War II.<ref>Koppel S. Pinson, ''Simon Dubnow'', p. 13-69, 1958.</ref> * The [[Partition of India|Partition]] of India and (later Pakistan ''and'' [[Bangladesh]]) arose as a result of separatism on the part of both Hindus and Muslims, as well as strong national identities on both sides. * [[Religion in Russia|Russia]], [[Religion in China|China]], [[Religion in India|India]], [[Religion in Thailand|Thailand]] and the [[Religion in the Philippines|Philippines]] have Muslim-separatist groups. * [[Sikh]]s in India sought an independent nation of [[Khalistan]] during the 1970s and 1980s. The [[Khalistan movement]] inside India largely ended with the Indian military [[Operation Blue Star]] against Sikh militants and the retaliatory assassination of the then [[Prime Minister of India]] [[Indira Gandhi]]. However, some in the Sikh diaspora still support such a movement.<ref>Blbir Punj, [http://www.sikhtimes.com/news_061605a.html The Ghost of Khalistan], [http://sikhtimes.com SikhTimes.com], June 16, 2006.</ref> * [[Tibetan Buddhists]] in China.
===Ethnic=== [[File:Paisos catalans belfast.jpg|right|upright|thumb|190px|Catalan independentist mural in [[Belfast]].]] [[Image:3 Marsz Autonomii 012.jpg|right|thumb|190px|[[Silesia]]ns demonstrating in [[Katowice]] (in Silesia).]]
[[Ethnic]] separatism is based more on cultural and linguistic differences than [[Religion|religious]] or [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial]] differences, which also may exist. Notable ethnic separatist movements include:
* the [[Kurdish people]] whose lands and peoples were divided between Turkey, [[Syria]], [[Iraq]] after World War I. Also the Kurdish region in [[Iran]]. * the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] separatists in [[Niger]] and [[Mali]].<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L2046634.htm Niger, hit by Tuareg revolt, adopts anti-terror law ]. Reuters. April 20, 2008.</ref> * the Soviet Union's dissolution into its original ethnic groupings which formed their own nations of [[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Belarus]], [[Estonia]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Moldova]], Russia, [[Tajikistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Ukraine]], and [[Uzbekistan]]. * [[Chechen people|Chechen]] separatism in the [[Caucasus]], currently the [[Republic of Chechnya]] is part of the [[Russian Federation]] (Russian rule). * [[Silesia]]n separatism in Poland and [[Czech Republic]]. * [[Armenians|Armenian]] separatists of [[Nagorno-Karabakh]] in [[Azerbaijan]]. * [[South Ossetia]] and [[Abkhazia]] separatism in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. * Spain's [[Basque separatism|Basque]], [[Galician nationalism|Galician]] and [[Catalan separatism|Catalan]] separatists. Minor separatist movements in [[Andalusian nationalism|Andalusia]], [[Asturian nationalism|Asturias]], [[Catalan nationalism|Balearic Islands]], [[Canarian nationalism|Canary Islands]], [[Castilian nationalism|Castile]] (almost non-existent), [[Leonese nationalism|León]], [[Basque nationalism|Navarre]] and [[Valencian nationalism|Valencia]] (see [[nationalisms and regionalisms of Spain]]). * "[[Celtic Nations]]"<ref>{{Cite web|title=Who were the Celts? ... Rhagor|url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1939/|accessdate=2009-12-10|publisher=[[National Museum Cardiff|Amgueddfa Cymru – National Museum Wales]]|date=2007-05-04|work=Amgueddfa Cymru – National Museum Wales website}}</ref> in the [[British Isles]] have created various separatist movements from the United Kingdom described as [[Scottish independence]], [[Welsh Nationalism]], [[Irish Republicanism]] and [[Cornish Nationalism]]. * France's [[Basque separatism|Basque]], [[Catalan separatism|Catalan]], [[Corsican Nationalist Alliance|Corsican]], [[Breton nationalism|Breton]] and [[Savoyan League|Savoyan]] separatists. * Italy's [[Venetian nationalism|Venetian]], [[Sardinian nationalism|Sardinian]] and [[Sicilian Independence Movement|Sicilian]] separatists; separatist movements of [[Northern Italy]] called [[Padania]]. * [[Bavaria]]n separatism in Germany, despite the Bavarian ''[[Lands of Germany|Land]]'' is referred to as the [[Bavarian Free State]]. *[[Czechoslovakia]]'s split into ethnic [[Czech Republic|Czech]] and [[Slovakia]]n republics in 1993. * the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] dissolution into ethnic (and religious) based [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Croatia]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Montenegro]], [[Serbia]] and [[Kosovo]]. * Belgium granting Dutch-speaking [[Flanders]] and French-speaking [[Wallonia]] greater autonomy. * In the Netherlands some [[Frisians]] covet an autonomous country or area ([[Friese beweging]]). *Switzerland's division into [[Cantons of Switzerland|cantons]] along geographical, religious and linguistic lines.<ref>Harold E. Glass, [http://www.jstor.org/pss/3329496 Ethnic Diversity, Elite Accommodation and Federalism in Switzerland], Publius, Vol. 7, No. 4, Federalism and Ethnicity (Autumn, 1977), 31-48. [[Oxford University Press]].</ref> * French-speaking [[Quebec]] debating and voting on separation from Canada over several decades. It is unclear if this is a matter of ethnic, linguistic or territorial [[Quebec nationalism|nationalism]]. *Africa's [[List of African ethnic groups|hundreds of ethnic groups]]<ref>[http://web.uflib.ufl.edu/cm/africana/ethnicit.htm African Ethnicities] [[University of Florida]] online library.</ref> are subsumed into 53 nation states, often leading to ethnic conflict and separatism,<ref>[http://web.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v3/v3i3a5.htm Excerpt from book Ethnic Conflicts in Africa, Okwudiba Nnoli, Distributed by African Books Collective, 1998, 417], University of Florida online library.</ref> including in [[Angola]], [[Algeria]], [[Burundi]], [[Republic of the Congo|Congo]] and [[The Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Darfur]] in [[Sudan]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Senegal]], [[Somalia]], [[South Africa]], [[Uganda]], [[Western Sahara]] and [[Zimbabwe]]. * The [[Nigerian civil war]] (also known as the Biafran war) during the 1960s among [[Igbos]], [[Hausa-Fulani]] and [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]]; today's ethnic and oil-related [[conflict in the Niger Delta]] of Nigeria. * Conflicts in [[Liberia]] between African-Liberians and Americo-Liberians, Africans who immigrated from the Americas after being freed from [[slavery]]. * Conflicts between [[Zulu people|Zulu]]s and [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] in [[South Africa]] during and after [[separate development|apartheid]].<ref>Emmy Godwin Irobi, [http://www.beyondintractability.org/case_studies/nigeria_south-africa.jsp?nid=6720 Ethnic Conflict Management in Africa: A Comparative Case Study of Nigeria and South Africa], May, 2005, Conflict Research Consortium, [[University of Colorado, Boulder]].</ref> * [[Boere-Afrikaner]] separatists.[[File:PKK Militant.jpg|thumb|190px|A [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] [[Kurdistan Workers' Party|PKK]] guerrilla in Iraqi Kurdistan as part of the [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict]].]] * [[Anjouan]]'s separatism in [[Union of Comoros]] as the island is a separate community from that of [[Comoros]]. * [[Separatist movements of Pakistan]] including [[Baloch nationalism|Balochistan movement]], [[Sindhi nationalism|Sindhudesh movement]] and [[Pashtun nationalism|Pashtunistan movement]].<ref name="Adeney">[http://www.palgrave.com/products/title.aspx?is=1403971862 Reviews of Katharine Adeney ''Federalism and Ethnic Conflict Regulation in India and Pakistan''], Palgrame MacMillan, 2007.</ref> * [[Separatist movements of India]] including [[Separate Statehood movement of Telangana]],<ref>[[Telangana]]</ref> [[Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir]] and [[Insurgent groups in Northeast India]]<ref name="Adeney"/><ref>S.D. Muini, [http://www.unu.edu/unupress/unupbooks/uu12ee/uu12ee0j.htm Ethnic conflict, federalism, and democracy in India], Chapter 10 of ''Ethnicity and power in the contemporary world'', Edited by Kumar Rupesinghe and Valery A. Tishkov, United Nations University Press, 1996.</ref> * [[Sri Lanka]]'s ethnic [[Tamil people|Tamil]] minority separatism in [[Tamil Eelam]]. * [[Burma]] (Union of Myanmar)'s ethnic [[Arakanese people|Arakan]], [[Chin State|Chin]], [[Kachin State|Kachin]], [[Karen people|Karen]], [[Shan State|Shan]], [[Wa State|Wa]] separatism. *Azeri separatists in Iran want to re-unite the provinces of [[East Azerbaijan]], [[West Azerbaijan]], [[Zanjan, Iran|Zanjan]] and [[Ardabil]] with [[Azerbaijan]]. * [[Free Papua Movement]] in [[West Papua (region)|West Papua]], [[Indonesia]]. * China's [[Tibet Autonomous Region|Tibet]] has a separatist [[government in exile]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gEx2K2kbCWBACX-kT0_jDbuoWr0w|title=China issues call to crush Tibetan 'separatists'|date=2009-02-19|accessdate=2010-07-29|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gEx2K2kbCWBACX-kT0_jDbuoWr0w}}</ref> * [[Māori people|Māori]] separatism in New Zealand. * The breakup of the [[Habsburg Empire]] into ethnic-based states. * The breakup of the [[Ottoman Empire]] into ethnic based states. * Ethnic-based separatism among Turkic groups in [[Xinjiang]] ([[Uighurs]]). * Hispanic (mostly Chicano) separatism, as embodied in the [[Chicano Movement]] (or [[Chicano nationalism|Chicano nation]]) in the United States sought to recreate [[Aztlán]], the mythical homeland of the [[Uto-Aztecan languages|Uto-Aztec]]s comprising the [[Southwestern United States]] which is home to the majority of [[Mexican Americans]].<ref name="aztlan.net">[http://www.aztlan.net/homeland.htm Professor Predicts 'Hispanic Homeland'], Associated Press, 2000</ref> They drew on the [[Latin American]] concepts of racial identity such as the [[bronze race]] and [[La Raza Cósmica]]. Today a small [[Raza Unida Party]] continues with similar goals.
===Racial=== {{Globalize|section|date = August 2011}} Some groups seek to separate from others along [[Racism|racialist]] lines. They oppose inter-marriage with other races and seek separate schools, businesses, churches and other institutions or even separate societies, territories and governments.[[image:Aztlán in United States (US48).svg|thumb|Territories considered for [[Reconquista (Mexico)|Republica del Norte]] ("Aztlán")]] * [[Black separatism]] (or [[black nationalism]]) is a reaction to slavery in the United states and has been advanced by black leaders like [[Marcus Garvey]] and the [[Nation of Islam]]. [[Critical race theory|Critical race theorists]] like [[New York University]]'s [[Derrick Bell]] and [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]]'s [[Richard Delgado]] argue the American legal, education and political party systems are rife with racism. They support efforts like all-black schools and dorms and question the efficacy of government-enforced integration.<ref>Franklin Foer, [http://www.slate.com/id/1080/ Racial Integration], [[Slate (magazine)|''Slate'']], November 23, 1997.</ref> In 2008 statements by Barack Obama's former pastor [[Jeremiah Wright, Jr.]] revived the issue of the current relevance of black separatism.<ref>Rich Barlow, [http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2008/04/26/theological_topic_turns_to_wright_case/Theological Topic turns to Wright case], ''[[The Boston Globe|Boston Globe]]'', April 26, 2008.</ref> * [[Latin American]] concepts of racial identity such as the [[bronze race]] and [[La Raza Cósmica]] found in the small separatist [[Raza Unida Party]]. The [[Chicano Movement]] (or [[Chicano nationalism|Chicano nation]]) in the United States sought to recreate [[Aztlán]], the mythical homeland of the [[Aztec]]s comprising the [[Southwestern United States]].<ref name="aztlan.net"/> * [[White separatism]] in the United States and Western Europe seeks separation and survival of the white race and limits to [[immigration]] by non-whites. According to two sociologists writing in the year 2000, most separatists now reject any ideology of [[white supremacy]], though advocacy groups continue to demonize such separatist groups.<ref>Betty A. Dobratz, Stephanie L. Shanks-Meile, ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=r59bGyH4lOAC The White Separatist Movement in the United States: "White Power, White Pride!"]'', [[The Johns Hopkins University Press]], 2000, 1-3, 10.</ref> * Most [[North American]] and many other [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] groups already have a high degree of autonomy. Complete separatism is advocated by some members of the Canadian [[First Nations]], [[American Indian Movement]], [[Republic of Lakotah]] ([[Lakota Sioux]] people in [[South Dakota]]), the [[Navajo people|Navajo]] or "Na-Dene" Nationalists in [[Arizona]] and tribal groups in [[Eastern Oklahoma]], most notably the [[Cherokee]] people of the [[Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma]]. {{Citation needed|date=June 2008}}
===Gender=== [[Separatist feminism]] is women's choosing to separate from ostensibly male-defined, male-dominated institutions, relationships, roles and activities.<ref>Marilyn Frye, "Some Reflections on Separatism and Power" in ''Feminist Social Thought: A Reader'', Diana Tietjens Meyers (ed.) Routledge, 1997, 406-414.</ref> [[Lesbian separatism]] advocates [[lesbian]]ism as the logical result of feminism. Some separatist feminists and lesbian separatists have chosen to live apart in [[intentional community]], [[cooperatives]], and on [[land trust]]s.<ref>Joyce Cheney, ''Lesbian Land'', Word Weavers Press, 1976.</ref> "Gay" separatism including both lesbians and gay men holds they should form a community distinct and separate from other groups.<ref>Mark K. Bloodsworth-Lugo, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Ph74JKY_5dwC&dq=LGBTQ&lr=&num=50&as_brr=3&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 ''In-Between Bodies: Sexual Difference, Race, and Sexuality''], SUNY Press, 2007, ISBN 0-7914-7221-3</ref><ref>Richard D. Mohr, [http://books.google.com/books?id=dfUw8Zl0kPEC ''Gays/Justice: A Study of Ethics, Society, and Law''], Columbia University Press, 1988, ISBN 0-231-06735-6</ref>
